questions.text: Which theory of disease causation emphasises the role of genetic predisposition and environmental factors in the development of diseases?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Multifactorial Theory

Explanation: The Multifactorial Theory of disease causation emphasizes that diseases are not caused by a single factor but by a combination of genetic predisposition, environmental influences, lifestyle choices, culture, and physiological factors.

Theory

Description

Miasma Theory

(Option A)

Suggests that diseases are caused by "bad air" or miasmas, disease occurrence is associated with environmental conditions.

Germ Theory

(Option B)

States that microorganisms (germs) are the primary cause of many diseases, given by Louis Pasteur.

Epidemiological Triad Theory

(Option D)

Describes the interaction between the agent, host, and environment.

questions.text: Which aspect of a disease does the Case Fatality Rate (CFR) primarily measure ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Virulence
 

Explanation:

The Case Fatality Rate (CFR) is closely related to virulence, representing the killing power of a disease. It is calculated as the ratio of deaths to cases, without specifying a time interval, using the formula:

  • CFR is a proportion, not a rate.
  • CFR is typically used for acute infectious diseases (e.g., food poisoning, cholera, measles) but is less useful for chronic diseases due to the long and variable period from onset to death.
  • The CFR for the same disease can vary across different epidemics due to agent, host, and environmental changes.
  • CSR (Case survival rate) = 100-CFR
 

Definition

Virulence

The degree of severity or harmfulness of a disease, measuring the proportion of severe or fatal cases.

Infectivity

(Option A)

The ability of a pathogen to establish an infection and spread among a population.

Pathogenicity

(Option B)

The ability of a microorganism to cause disease determines whether an infection will manifest as an illness.

Transmissibility

(Communicability)

(Option D)

The ability of a disease to be transmitted from one host to another indicates how easily it spreads. This is measured by Secondary attack rate.

questions.text: Why is the web of causation models considered beneficial for public health interventions?

choices.text: It identifies a single cause for targeted intervention.
It suggests that only one factor needs to be addressed for disease control.
It highlights multiple points where interventions can reduce disease occurrence.
It eliminates the need for further research.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) It highlights multiple points where interventions can reduce disease occurrence.

Explanation:

  • The web of causation model is beneficial because it identifies the complex interrelationships of multiple factors contributing to disease.
  • By mapping these relationships, public health professionals can identify several intervention points, providing various strategies to reduce disease occurrence.
  • It is ideal for studying chronic diseases where the disease agent is often unknown.
  • Epidemiology studies clusters of causes and their effects, showing various possible interventions to reduce disease occurrence.
  • In multifactorial events, individual factors have different levels of importance.
  • The relative importance of individual factors can be expressed as "relative risk".

questions.text: Which of the following diseases does NOT follow the spectrum of disease principle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Rabies

Explanation:

Rabies progresses rapidly from initial infection to severe neurological symptoms and death without distinct stages of varying severity.

Diseases like Leprosy (Option A), Influenza (Option B), and Tuberculosis (Option D) have distinct stages of varying severity.

Spectrum of Disease:

  • It represents the range of variations in disease manifestations.
  • This difference in manifestation reflects individual differences in immunity and susceptibility.
  • Leprosy exemplifies the spectrum of disease principles, showing varying severities.
  • Significance: The spectrum of disease includes both subclinical and clinical cases, facilitating comprehensive disease study.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases typically does not exhibit a large hidden portion according to the Iceberg phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Measles

Explanation:

Measles typically does not exhibit a large hidden portion in the Iceberg phenomenon due to its highly recognizable symptoms, lack of long-term asymptomatic carriers, and prompt clinical diagnosis.

Iceberg phenomenon of disease:

  • It suggests that some diseases have a significant portion of undiagnosed or asymptomatic cases, while only a small portion is diagnosed and visible.
  • The "tip of the iceberg" denotes diagnosed cases or apparent infections of concern to physicians, where diagnostic tests are applied.
  • The "hidden portion" includes undiagnosed or asymptomatic individuals of concern to epidemiologists, who may appear healthy but harbor the disease's pathogenesis.

Diseases that follow the Iceberg phenomenon

Diseases that don't follow the Iceberg phenomenon
  • Non-communicable diseases
  • Cancer
  • Protein-energy malnutrition cases
  • Tuberculosis
  • HIV/AIDS
  • Measles
  • Rabies (Highest CFR rate)
  • Tetanus

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the Physical quality of life index (PQLI)?

choices.text: Measures gross national income (GNI) per capita

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Measures the infant mortality rate

Explanation:

The physical quality of life index (PQLI) includes the infant mortality rate as one of its three components.

Differentiating features between PQLI and HDI:

Physical quality of life index (PQLI)

Human Development Index (HDI)

PQLI is a measure developed to assess the general well-being of a population.

HDI is a composite measure that evaluates human development across three dimensions: health, education, and standard of living.

Components:

  • Life expectancy at one year of age
  • Literacy rate
  • Infant mortality rate (Option B)

Components:

  • Life expectancy at birth (Option A)
  • Knowledge index or educational index = (EYS + MYS)/2
  • Gross national income per capita (Option C)
  • HDI is a geometric mean of all dimension indices

Evaluated on a scale of 0-100

Evaluated on a scale of 0-1 (Option D)

EYS = Expected Year of School; MYS = Mean Year of School

questions.text: A public health researcher analyses data to understand gender disparities in human development within a specific region. The researcher is particularly interested in the components used to calculate the Gender Development Index (GDI). All of the following are components of the GDI except?

choices.text: Life expectancy at birth for both males and females
Education index of both males and females
Infant mortality rates of both males and females
Standard of living for both males and females

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Infant mortality rates of both males and females.

Explanation:

The Gender Development Index (GDI) assesses gender disparities in three fundamental areas of human development:

  • Life expectancy at birth.
  • Knowledge: Male adult literacy rate + Male gross enrollment ratio and female adult literacy rate + female gross enrollment ratio.
  • Standard of living: Estimated earned income for both males and females.

As per the HDR 2022, India's GDI value is 0.852, with the GDI value for females standing at 0.582 and that for males at 0.684.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indicator of the human poverty index?

choices.text: The proportion of people not surviving until the age of 40 years
No access to safe water supply and sanitation

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Occupation and income

Explanation:

The Human Poverty Index (HPI) does not typically consider occupation and income. It focuses more on deprivation in basic human capabilities and social indicators rather than solely on income or occupation.

  • The Human Poverty Index (HPI) was developed to measure relative poverty, which refers to the lack of access to other facilities and services.
  • Indicators of HPI:
    • Longevity: The proportion of people not surviving until the age of 40 years).
    • Knowledge: Adult Literacy Rate
    • Standard of living: No access to safe water supply and sanitization and % of children underweight.
  • HPI 1 is used for developing countries, and HPI 2 is used for developed countries.
  • In 2010, HPI was replaced by the Multidimensional Poverty Index( MDPI).

questions.text: How does the Multidimensional Poverty Index (MPI) offer a more comprehensive view of poverty than traditional income-based measures?

choices.text: By measuring only the income levels of households.
By focusing solely on the employment status of individuals.
By including various indicators of health, education, and living standards.
By evaluating the GDP per capita of the country.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) By including various indicators of health, education, and living standards.

Explanation:

  • Multidimensional poverty index (MDPI) complements traditional monetary poverty measures by simultaneously capturing the acute deprivations in:
    • Health
    • Education 
    • Living standards of the person
  • MDPI is interpreted in the range of 0-1.
  • The use of MDPI is the measure of acute poverty.
  • India’s MDPI is 0.121, with a 27.5% poor population.
  • The Human Poverty Index (HPI) was replaced by the MDPI in 2010, as it was not specific to any group of people.
  • Individuals are classified as multidimensionally deprived if they fall short in at least one dimension or in a combination of indicators that total the weight of a full dimension.
  • Households are considered poor if deprived in indicators adding up to 1/3 or more.

Dimensions of Poverty

Indicator

Health

Nutrition (1/6)

Child mortality (1/6)

Education

Years of schooling (1/6)

School attendance (1/6)

Standard of living

Cooking Fuel (1/18)

Sanitation (1/18)

Drinking Water (1/18)

Electricity (1/18)

Housing (1/18)

Assets (1/18)


Options A, B, and D are not included in the Multidimensional poverty index(MDPI)

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the Global Hunger Index?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Infant mortality rate

Explanation:

  • The Global Hunger Index (GHI) does not include the Infant mortality rate.
  • It measures three dimensions of hunger:
    • Food availability (Option D)
    • Child's nutritional status (Option B) 
    • Child mortality due to undernutrition (Option C)
  • It includes three equally weighted indicators(arithmetic mean): 
    • The proportion of people who are food energy-deficient (FAO estimates)
    • Prevalence of underweight children under 5 years (WHO data)
    • Mortality rate of children under 5 years (UNICEF reports)

In 2022, India's GHI rank was 107 out of the 121 countries with sufficient data to calculate 2022 GHI scores. With a score of 29.1, India has a serious level of hunger.
